title: Question 78

children: A 57-year-old woman is evaluated for progressive dyspnea of 1 year's duration. She has otherwise been well and takes no medications.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 121/82 mm Hg.

children.referenceRange: Blood gases, Oxygen saturation, arterial (ambient air)

is 94% with the patient breathing ambient air. There is a grade 2/6 systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border that increases with inspiration and persistent splitting of S

but are otherwise normal. Ventilation/perfusion scan is low probability for pulmonary embolism.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Pulmonary hypertension should be suspected in patients with progressive dyspnea, elevated central venous pressure, prominent venous
a
wave, fixed splitting of S
, and the murmur of tricuspid regurgitation.
Right heart catheterization and measurement of pulmonary artery pressure is the diagnostic gold standard for pulmonary hypertension.
The most appropriate next step for this patient is right heart catheterization (
Option B
). This patient has symptoms (progressive dyspnea) and signs (elevated central venous pressure, venous
a
wave, fixed splitting of S

, tricuspid regurgitation) of pulmonary hypertension (PH). If PH is suspected, transthoracic echocardiography can estimate pulmonary artery systolic pressure. However, echocardiography does not confirm the diagnosis of PH because pressure estimation by echocardiography may be inaccurate. Right heart catheterization confirms the diagnosis of PH and is an essential component of the diagnostic evaluation. Guidelines recommend referral of patients with severe pulmonary hypertension or right ventricular dysfunction to a pulmonary hypertension referral center. Data suggest that patients who are evaluated for pulmonary hypertension outside of pulmonary hypertension referral centers receive an incorrect diagnosis as much as 33% of the time. The evaluation of PH also includes additional testing to identify an underlying cause of PH such as lung disease, left-sided heart failure, chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension, and causes of nocturnal hypoxemia.
Coronary angiography (
Option A

) might be considered if ischemic cardiomyopathy with left ventricular failure is suspected as the cause of PH. However, this patient has no symptoms or ECG or echocardiographic findings to support this diagnosis. Coronary angiography is not indicated.

The current classification system subdivides PH into five groups, which are based on similarities in mechanisms, hemodynamics, clinical presentation, and approach to treatment. Group 1 includes patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), including those with idiopathic and heritable disease, and disease related to drugs and toxins, connective tissue diseases, HIV infection, schistosomiasis, congenital heart disease, and portal hypertension. High-dose calcium channel blockers, such as nifedipine (
Option C

), can be effective treatment in a small number of group 1 patients who are “vasoreactive” by demonstrating marked improvement in mean pulmonary artery pressure with administration of nitric oxide, epoprostenol, or adenosine during right heart catheterization. Sildenafil (
Option D

), a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor, may be effective in mild to moderate PAH in the absence of vasoreactivity. However, neither nifedipine nor sildenafil is indicated for the treatment of PAH until the diagnosis of PH has been confirmed and other causes of PH have been excluded.

references: Klinger JR, Elliott CG, Levine DJ, et al. Therapy for pulmonary arterial hypertension in adults: update of the CHEST guideline and expert panel report. Chest. 2019;155:565-586.
